audio.transcript: Dr. John Gottman, a researcher on emotions, first began conducting studies on couple interaction in the 1970's. As time passed he noticed that the stress level between couples went up when the first child was born. Gottman's research team then began focusing on the parent-child interaction within these families.

They found that couples who valued each other's emotions also valued their children's emotions. Parenting styles were then categorized into four types based on the emotional connection between the parent and their child. Over his years of research, Gottman discovered that parenting behaviors are shaped by the attitudes and feelings parents have about parenting. Children respond to parent-child interactions through their behavior. Parental interaction is important because it sets the stage for a child's future social-emotional development. Now that you're familiar with Gottman's research, the ideas of attunement and meta-emotions will be easier to understand. These concepts will be discussed in detail in the lessons that follow.

This research can be summarized in the following key messages for this section: Children raised by parents who value and guide emotions do better in many ways. Parenting is the way an adult interacts with their child and teaching children about emotions is an important first step in helping children learn to manage the emotion. There is no such thing as a bad emotion; it's how we handle emotions that matters.
